trans-unit.source: Controls how a document is printed from a Windows Forms application.
This class implements a <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController> and adds a status dialog box.
A print controller specifies how a <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument> is printed.
For a list of initial property values for an instance of the PrintControllerWithStatusDialog class, see the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.%23ctor%2A> constructor.
For more information about printing with Windows Forms, see the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing> namespace overview.
If you want to print from a Windows Presentation Foundation application, see the <xref:System.Printing> namespace.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog"></xref> class, wrapping the supplied <xref href="System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController"></xref>.
A <xref href="System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController"></xref> to encapsulate.

Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog"></xref> class, wrapping the supplied <xref href="System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController"></xref> and specifying a title for the dialog box.
A <xref href="System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController"></xref> to encapsulate.
A <xref:System.String> containing a title for the status dialog box.
Gets a value indicating this <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog"></xref> is used for print preview.
The IsPreview checks the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController.IsPreview%2A> property of the underlying controller.

<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog"></xref> is used for print preview, otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Completes the control sequence that determines when and how to print a page of a document.

The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog> class calls the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController.OnEndPage%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method on the encapsulated <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController>.
The OnEndPage method is called immediately after the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument> raises the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument.PrintPage> event.
If an exception is thrown inside a <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument.PrintPage> event of a <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument>, OnEndPage is not called.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnStartPrint%2A> method creates the <xref:System.Drawing.Graphics> object that is sent to the printer.

After <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnStartPrint%2A> is called, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnStartPage%2A> method sets the <xref:System.Drawing.Graphics> object to a graphic of a single page.
(Use <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnStartPage%2A> to set how to print a page in a document.

For example, you can adjust page settings separately for each page.) OnEndPage clears the <xref:System.Drawing.Graphics> object, while the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnEndPrint%2A> method deallocates the object.
A <xref href="System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument"></xref> that represents the document currently being printed.
A <xref href="System.Drawing.Printing.PrintPageEventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
Completes the control sequence that determines when and how to print a document.

The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog> class calls the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController.OnEndPrint%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method on the encapsulated <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController>.
The OnEndPrint method is called immediately after the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument> raises the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument.EndPrint> event.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnStartPrint%2A> method creates the <xref:System.Drawing.Graphics> object that is sent to the printer.

After <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnStartPrint%2A> is called, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnStartPage%2A> method sets the <xref:System.Drawing.Graphics> object to a graphic of a single page.
(Use <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnStartPrint%2A> to determine when and how to print a document.

For example, you can delay printing for 30 minutes or adjust the printer settings for the document.) The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnEndPage%2A> method clears the <xref:System.Drawing.Graphics> object, while OnEndPrint deallocates the object.
A <xref href="System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument"></xref> that represents the document currently being printed.
A <xref href="System.Drawing.Printing.PrintPageEventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
Begins the control sequence that determines when and how to print a page of a document.

The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog> class calls the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController.OnStartPage%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method on the encapsulated <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController>.
The OnStartPage method is called immediately before the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument> raises the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument.PrintPage> event.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnStartPrint%2A> method creates the <xref:System.Drawing.Graphics> object that is sent to the printer.
After <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnStartPrint%2A> is called, OnStartPage sets the <xref:System.Drawing.Graphics> object to a graphic of a single page.

The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnEndPage%2A> method clears the <xref:System.Drawing.Graphics> object, while the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnEndPrint%2A> method deallocates the object.
Use OnStartPage to set how to print a page in a document.
For example, you can adjust page settings separately for each page.
A <xref href="System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument"></xref> that represents the document currently being printed.
A <xref href="System.Drawing.Printing.PrintPageEventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
A <xref href="System.Drawing.Graphics"></xref> object that represents a page from a <xref href="System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument"></xref>.
Begins the control sequence that determines when and how to print a document.

The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog> class calls the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController.OnStartPrint%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method on the encapsulated <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintController>.
The OnStartPrint method is called immediately after the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument> raises the <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument.BeginPrint> event.
Use OnStartPrint to determine when and how to print a document.
For example, you can delay printing for 30 minutes or adjust the printer settings for the document.
OnStartPrint creates the <xref:System.Drawing.Graphics> object that is sent to the printer.
After OnStartPrint is called, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnStartPage%2A> method sets the <xref:System.Drawing.Graphics> object to a graphic of a single page.

The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnEndPage%2A> method clears the <xref:System.Drawing.Graphics> object, while the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.PrintControllerWithStatusDialog.OnEndPrint%2A> method deallocates the object.
OnStartPrint is a good place to verify that <xref:System.Drawing.Printing.PrinterSettings> are valid.
A <xref href="System.Drawing.Printing.PrintDocument"></xref> that represents the document currently being printed.
A <xref href="System.Drawing.Printing.PrintEventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
